markdownRemark.html:
Being a team lead has felt new. I was just recognized last week by my old manager during a large meeting about how I’ve been leading this new team. I guess I’ve been doing okay.

So far, my team consists of 2 other guys, with me being split 80/20 as software engineer and project manager. One guy came from finance startups, as an analyst (?), who learned how to program with the help of bootcamps. The other guy was previously an elementary school teacher, who also went through a bootcamp. This would be his first job as a Software Engineer. For everyone involved, this team has been a cool learning experience.

As the OG one of the company, I know the ins and outs of the services we use, and the tooling needed to deploy a new application. I’ve been the guide for most of the processes by sharing how we do things around the company. I also noticed that I like sharing ideas on the white board, but I’ve also been careful not to overdo it. I’m the go-to in terms of automating GitHub Pull Request checks and having automated builds & deployments to our different environments. The industry calls that “CI/CD”, but I don’t care to remember which is which.

Our application is the start to a “Supplier Ecosystem” that the company is trying to build. It’s to help onboard suppliers who are trying to sell their products either on the online store or in stores. Currently, the process to onboard these people is time-consuming, email-centric, and not very centralized. It’s worth mentioning that our application introduces new measurements and data that was not able to be done before.
